articles.author: Jhey Tompkins
articles.description:
Howdy y‚Äôall! Unless you‚Äôve been living under a rock (and maybe even then), you‚Äôve undoubtedly heard the news that CSS-Tricks, was acquired by DigitalOcean. Congratulations to everyone! ü•≥
As a little hurrah to commemorate the occasion, I wanted to ‚Ä¶
Creating the DigitalOcean Logo in 3D With CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Creating the DigitalOcean Logo in 3D With CSS

articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
In my last article, we went over how to set up a web app that serves chunks and bundles of CSS and JavaScript from CloudFront. We integrated it into Vite so that when the app runs in a browser, ‚Ä¶
Setting Up CloudFront to Host Your Web App originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Setting Up CloudFront to Host Your Web App

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
A while ago, Geoff wrote an article about a cool hover effect. The effect relies on a combination of CSS pseudo-elements, transforms, and transitions. A lot of comments have shown that the same effect can be done using background ‚Ä¶
Cool Hover Effects That Use Background Properties originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Cool Hover Effects That Use Background Properties

articles.author: Dan Christofi
articles.description:
When creating a component-based, front-end infrastructure, one of the biggest pain points I‚Äôve personally encountered is making components that are both reusable and responsive when there are nested components within components.
Take the following ‚Äúcall to action‚Äù (<CTA />‚Ä¶
Avoiding the Pitfalls of Nested Components in a Design System originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Avoiding the Pitfalls of Nested Components in a Design System

articles.author: Mark Noonan
articles.description:
Automated front-end tests are awesome. We can write a test with code to visit a page ‚Äî or load up just a single component ‚Äî and have that test code click on things or type text like a user would, ‚Ä¶
Writing Strong Front-end Test Element Locators originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Writing Strong Front-end Test Element Locators

articles.author: Greg Sullivan
articles.description:
In the 15 or so years since I started making WordPress websites, nothing has had more of an impact on my productivity ‚Äî and my ability to enjoy front-end development ‚Äî than adding Tailwind CSS to my workflow (and it ‚Ä¶
Adding Tailwind CSS to New and Existing WordPress Themes originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding Tailwind CSS to New and Existing WordPress Themes

articles.author: Paul Esch-Laurent
articles.description:
Mermaid diagrams and flowcharts have been gaining traction, especially with GitHub‚Äôs announcement that they are natively supported in Markdown. Let‚Äôs take a look at what they are, how to use them, and just as importantly: why.
Just like you ‚Ä¶
Making Mermaid Diagrams in Markdown originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Making Mermaid Diagrams in Markdown

articles.author: Shimin Zhang
articles.description:
I‚Äôm a big fan of movies by J.J. Abrams. I enjoy their tight plots, quippy dialog, and of course: anamorphic lens flares. Filmmakers like Abrams use lens flare to add a dash of ‚Äòhomemade‚Äô realism to their movies, ‚Ä¶
Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch

articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
Content delivery networks, or CDNs, allow you to improve the delivery of your website‚Äôs static resources, most notably, with CDN caching. They do this by serving your content from edge locations, which are located all over the world. When a ‚Ä¶
Adding CDN Caching to a Vite Build originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding CDN Caching to a Vite Build

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let‚Äôs welcome May with a new collection of wallpapers. Designed with love by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for May 2022.
articles.title: Make A Wish (May 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Steve Sewell)
articles.description: Introducing Partytown, a lightweight open-source solution that reduces execution delays due to third-party JavaScript by offloading third-party scripts to web workers, which run in background threads.
articles.title: How Partytown Eliminates Website Bloat From Third-Party Scripts

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nathan Smith)
articles.description: In this article, Nathan Smith explains how to create modal dialog windows with rich interaction that will only require authoring HTML in order to be used. They are based on Web Components that are currently supported by every major browser.
articles.title: CTA Modal: How To Build A Web Component

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: We should be able to measure how well a particular design solves a particular problem. Let‚Äôs explore design KPIs that capture user‚Äôs experience, how to measure them and how to keep both users and business stakeholders happy, over time.
articles.title: Boosting UX With Design KPIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ceara Crawshaw)
